Title: Randomised Controlled Trial on Peripheral Nerve Injury After Varicose Vein Surgery Using Endovenous Laser Ablation

Background: This study aimed to evaluate peripheral nerve injury (PNI) after varicose vein (VV) surgery using endovenous laser ablation (EVLA).

Methods: A total of 25 patients were enrolled from 2021 to 2023, undergoing EVLA of the great saphenous vein (GSV) with or without microphlebectomy. The primary outcome was PNI, defined as >40% elevation in current perception threshold (CPT) from preoperative data, measured at 6 points on each leg preoperatively and at 1 week, 1 month, and 6 months postoperatively. Randomisation and allocation concealment methods were not applicable as this was not a randomised trial. Blinding was not implemented.

Results: Significant CPT elevation was observed at the knee joint level (P = 0.01) and upper portion of the lower leg (P = 0.008) 1 week postoperatively. CPT decreased after 1 month and returned to baseline after 6 months. PNI occurred in 52% and 36% of patients at the knee joint level and upper portion of the lower leg, respectively. Microphlebectomy was associated with PNI (P <0.01). No major complications were reported.

Interpretation: VV surgery using EVLA is less invasive, but transient PNI may occur early postoperatively, especially with concomitant microphlebectomy. Further studies are needed to confirm these findings.

Trial registration: Not provided.

Funding: None.
